item.title: 1976 Tehran UFO incident
item.description:
1976 Tehran UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The 1976 Tehran UFO incident involved radar and visual sightings of an unidentified flying object (UFO) over Tehran, Iran, in the early morning hours of September 19, 1976. Two Imperial Iranian Air Force (IIAF) F-4 Phantom II jet interceptors were dispatched to investigate. Pilots reported instrumentation and communication failures as they approached the object, which were restored upon withdrawal. One aircraft also experienced a temporary weapons systems failure while preparing to fire. An initial report was relayed to the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff on the day of the incident.

Incident ðŸ”—

On September 19, 1976, at least four civilians reported a shining object in the sky above Tehran. Lieutenant Yaddi Nazeri and a weapons officer were sent to investigate in an F-4 Phantom II. Nazeri reported losing all instruments and communications upon reaching Tehran, prompting a return to base where the instruments returned to normal.

Major Parviz Jafari, a squadron commander, and First Lieutenant Jalal Damirian were dispatched in a second F-4 Phantom II. Jafari acquired radar lock on an object 27 nautical miles away, estimating its size to be comparable to a Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker. As he approached, Jafari described the object as flashing intense red, green, orange, and blue lights. His plane’s communications system shut off. When he attempted to fire an AIM-9 Sidewinder missile, his equipment failed and only returned to normal after moving away.

Jafari reported a round object emerging from the primary object and moving towards him at high speed. His weapons control panel failed, and he lost all instruments and radio communication. Instructed to return to base, Jafari saw the primary, diamond-shaped object and another bright object descending towards the ground, emitting a bright light. The next day, Jafari and Damirian searched the area by helicopter but found nothing. Residents reported hearing a loud noise and seeing a bright flash of light.

Analysis ðŸ”—

Martin Bridgstock of Griffith University summarized the incident as Iranian air force jets investigating lights in the sky, with at least one jet experiencing electrical failures and an attempt to fire a missile. A nearby airliner also suffered radio failure.

Philip J. Klass suggested the pilots initially mistook Jupiter for a UFO. He attributed equipment failures to pilot incompetence and equipment malfunction. Klass noted that only the first F-4 reported equipment failure and had a history of electrical outages. A McDonnell Douglas repair supervisor suggested the radar might have been in “manual track” mode, leading to misinterpretation.

Bridgstock criticized UFOlogists’ reports and highlighted Klass’s findings that only one aircraft had electrical malfunctions and that the aircrews were tired and could have mistaken stars or meteors for UFOs.

Brian Dunning noted that the incident occurred during the peak of the Gamma Piscids and Southern Piscids meteorite showers, making observations of falling objects common. A beeping transponder from a C-141 aircraft was found at the supposed crash site. Dunning concluded that the Tehran 1976 UFO case was unusual only because planes chased celestial objects and experienced equipment failures.

Reference to incident in the media ðŸ”—

The Sightings television program covered the incident in 1994, interviewing participants. The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian listed it among their top 10 UFO sightings.

Gallery ðŸ”—

The gallery includes an editorial from the United States Air Force Security Services quarterly MIJI newsletter, which Dunning describes as a dramatized retelling of the incident offered as an editorial on jamming and interference.

See also ðŸ”—

Links to related articles including UFO sightings in Iran and a list of UFO sightings.

References ðŸ”—

A list of references is provided, including reports from the National Security Agency, articles from The Times, Columbia Journalism Review, The New Yorker, Herald-Tribune, Skeptoid.com, books by Leslie Kean and Philip J. Klass, and articles from The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian.

External links ðŸ”—

Links to external resources such as the original report, DIA reports, and articles from Skeptoid.com and NICAP.org.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1976_Tehran_UFO_incident

item.title: Big Sur UFO
item.description:
The Big Sur UFO ðŸ”—

This article details a reported UFO incident that allegedly occurred during a 1964 Air Force mission near Big Sur, California. The Air Force team was stationed on a mountaintop to film Atlas missile tests from Vandenberg Air Force Base.

Air Force deployment to Anderson Peak ðŸ”—

From August to November 1964, the U.S. Air Force deployed personnel to the Los Padres National Forest in California. They used a special telescope borrowed from Boston University to photograph missile launches from Vandenberg Air Force Base. Lt. Robert Jacobs was the commander for the Big Sur location, managed by the 1369th Photo Squadron. The team successfully filmed nine launches, including one of an Atlas missile called “Buzzing Bee,” capturing footage of a re-entry vehicle deploying decoy warheads. This technology was highly classified and designed to protect American nuclear weapons from Soviet interception.

Fringe claims of extra-terrestrials ðŸ”—

In 1982, Robert Jacobs wrote about the incident in the tabloid National Enquirer, claiming he had been part of a cover-up and was now breaking his silence. He described film footage of an unidentified object next to a warhead and a senior official’s reaction. Jacobs claimed he was instructed to never discuss the film. Major Florenz Mansmann reportedly confirmed Jacobs’ account in a 1987 letter. Robert Hastings, a UFO author, further popularized the story in 2007. In 2021, Jacobs participated in a press conference to discuss his interpretation of the incident.

Decoy warheads explanation ðŸ”—

Kingston A. George, the project engineer during the incident, disputed Jacob’s claims of extraterrestrial interference in the Skeptical Inquirer. George stated that he, too, had seen footage he wasn’t cleared to see and was instructed not to speak of it. However, George claims he knew the true purpose of the test: filming the deployment of decoy warheads and chaff to confuse enemy air defenses. He attributed the lights Jacobs reported to the explosive deployment of decoys and chaff, not a UFO energy beam.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including articles from Military.com, Skeptical Inquirer, National Enquirer, and MUFON UFO Journal.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the “Malmstrom UFO incident” Wikipedia page.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Sur_UFO

item.title: List of UFO sightings in the Czech Republic
item.description:
List of UFO Sightings in the Czech Republic ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in the Czech Republic, spanning from 1976 to 2009.

1976, Radkov ðŸ”—

In 1976, a family in Radkov witnessed a triangular, boomerang-shaped UFO while at a campfire. Two years later, a similar object was reportedly pursued by a military aircraft from Å½atec over Western Bohemia, without success. In 1992, similar objects were observed in Cheb, near Prague, and near DvÅ¯r KrÃ¡lovÃ©.

1987, Vranov ðŸ”—

The Vranov UFO incident, considered the most famous in the Czech Republic, occurred on July 12, 1987, in Vranov nad DyjÃ­ above the Vranov Reservoir. A helicopter regiment was ordered to pursue a black, cigar-shaped object first located near the Austrian border. Pilots were instructed to shoot it down, but the object’s erratic movements and the presence of vacationers below prevented them. First Lieutenant Jaroslav Å paÄek reported the object flew towards their helicopter, forcing them to dodge it. The object then moved at high speed over Brno, JaslovskÃ© Bohunice, and Bratislava before disappearing from radar.

1991, MiliÄÃ­n ðŸ”—

On July 12, 1991, a glowing round object was sighted near MiliÄÃ­n, causing panic among the local population. The sphere appeared randomly and silently followed people. Some witnesses reported seeing figures within the sphere, who allegedly left the sphere to “repair” something on a cottage roof, leaving behind large, four-fingered footprints. A local pastor reportedly told people it was a divine miracle and to remain silent.

1992, TÅ™i Sekery ðŸ”—

On May 5, 1992, military radars detected an object approaching the Czechoslovak border from Germany, crossing near TÅ™i Sekery and heading towards Hvozd. Fighter jets and helicopters were dispatched, but despite radar visibility and ground observers, pilots could not locate the object. The object reportedly headed towards Chomutov and disappeared near Jirkov.

1993, BorovÃ¡ ðŸ”—

On August 21, 1993, a man in BorovÃ¡ encountered a flatfish-shaped object hovering above the road. The object then moved and floated noiselessly. The following day, numerous UFO sightings of various shapes and sizes were reported across the Czech Republic.

2009 ðŸ”—

During late May 2009, multiple reports of flying objects emerged from various locations in the Czech Republic.

  • On May 23, 2009, four people near KlÃ­novec saw four orange lights flying at equal intervals. Similar objects were seen later that night above ChrÃ¡st near PlzeÅˆ.
  • On May 24, 2009, people in Å˜Ã­Äany observed three glowing spheres in the sky.
  • On May 25, 2009, a university professor, who wished to remain anonymous, reported seeing disc-shaped objects resembling car high beams above the Brno highway.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the main article “List of reported UFO sightings”.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including news articles and websites, providing evidence and further information on the reported UFO sightings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_the_Czech_Republic

item.title: Close encounter
item.description:
Close Encounter ðŸ”—

A close encounter, in ufology, is defined as an event where a person witnesses an unidentified flying object (UFO) at close range, reducing the likelihood of misidentification. The term and classification system were introduced by astronomer and UFO researcher J. Allen Hynek in his 1972 book, The UFO Experience: A Scientific Inquiry. While others have expanded on Hynek’s original categories, these extensions haven’t gained widespread acceptance due to a perceived lack of scientific rigor. Sightings beyond 150 meters are generally classified as daylight discs, nocturnal lights, or radar/visual reports.

Hynek’s Scale ðŸ”—

J. Allen Hynek created a six-level classification system for UFO sightings, arranged by proximity. The categories include:

  1. Nocturnal Lights: Unexplained lights observed in the night sky.
  2. Daylight Discs: UFOs seen during the day, typically disc-shaped or oval.
  3. Radar-Visual: UFO sightings confirmed by radar, intended to provide more concrete evidence, though atmospheric anomalies can sometimes explain radar propagation.
  4. Close Encounters of the First Kind (CE1): Visual sightings of a UFO at close range (less than 150 meters), displaying appreciable angular extension and detail.
  5. Close Encounters of the Second Kind (CE2): UFO events involving physical effects, such as interference with vehicles or electronics, animal reactions, physiological effects on witnesses, or physical traces like ground impressions or scorched vegetation.
  6. Close Encounters of the Third Kind (CE3): UFO encounters where animated entities are present, including humanoids, robots, or humans seemingly associated with the UFO.

Bloecher Subtypes ðŸ”—

Ted Bloecher proposed six subtypes for Close Encounters of the Third Kind:

  1. Aboard: An entity is observed only inside the UFO.
  2. Both: An entity is observed both inside and outside the UFO.
  3. Close: An entity is observed near a UFO, but not entering or exiting it.
  4. Direct: An entity is observed without any UFOs being seen, but UFO activity has been reported in the area around the same time.
  5. Excluded: An entity is observed, but no UFOs are seen, and no UFO activity has been reported in the area at that time.
  6. Frequence: No entity or UFOs are observed, but the subject experiences some form of “intelligent communication.”

Extensions of Hynek’s Scale ðŸ”—

Following Hynek’s death in 1986, Jacques Vallee expanded the classification system by adding Close Encounters of the Fourth and Fifth Kinds, detailed in his 1990 book, Confrontations: A Scientist’s Search for Alien Contact. These extensions were quickly adopted by the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON).

Close Encounters of the Fourth Kind (CE4) ðŸ”—

A CE4 involves a human being abducted by a UFO or its occupants. Jacques VallÃ©e suggested that the “fourth kind” should encompass cases where witnesses experience a transformation of their sense of reality, including non-abduction events with absurd, hallucinatory, or dreamlike elements associated with UFO encounters.

Close Encounters of the Fifth Kind (CE5) ðŸ”—

In Vallee’s original definition, a CE5 occurs when an alien abductee experiences a physical effect from the encounter, such as injury or healing.

An alternate interpretation, popularized by Steven M. Greer, defines CE5 as human-initiated contact with extraterrestrial life forms or advanced interstellar civilizations, involving direct communication between aliens and humans. This involves individuals or groups using specific protocols, primarily contact meditation and sounds or signals, to establish communication or interaction with extraterrestrial beings. This is also referred to as human-initiated close encounter.

Close Encounters of the Sixth Kind (CE6) ðŸ”—

This term describes a sexual encounter between a human and an extraterrestrial species.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_encounter

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Flying Saucer ðŸ”—

A flying saucer, or flying disc, is a purported type of disc-shaped unidentified flying object (UFO). The term originated in 1947 when US news media reported pilot Kenneth Arnold’s claim of seeing objects flying near his airplane over Washington State. The news reports included implausible speed estimates and preceded a wave of sightings across the US, including the Roswell incident and the Flight 105 UFO sighting. A National Guard pilot died in 1948 while pursuing a flying saucer. Civilian research groups and conspiracy theories developed around the topic, and the concept spread to other countries. Early reports speculated about secret military technology, but flying saucers became associated with aliens by 1950. The terms unidentified flying object (UFO) and unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) have gradually replaced the term over time.

An aerial photo taken over Lake Cote, Costa Rica, by Sergio Loaiza in 1971 is included.

In science fiction, UFO sightings, UFO conspiracy theories, and popular culture, saucers are typically piloted by nonhuman beings. Most reported sightings describe saucers in the distance and do not mention a crew. Descriptions of the craft vary considerably. Early reports emphasized speed, but the descriptions shifted over the decades to the objects mostly hovering. They are generally said to be round, sometimes with a protrusion on top, but details of the shape vary between reports. Witnesses describe flying saucers as silent or deafening, with lights of every color, and flying alone or in formation. Size estimates range from small enough to fit in a living room to over 2,000 feet (610 m) in diameter. Sightings are most frequent at night. Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel concluded that the reports were too varied to all be describing the same type of objects. Experts have identified most reported saucers as known phenomena, including astronomical objects such as Venus, airborne objects such as balloons, and optical phenomena such as sun dogs.

1950s pop culture embraced flying saucers. The discs appeared in film, television, literature, music, toys, and advertising. Their reports influenced religious movements and were the subject of military investigations. The shape became visual shorthand for alien invaders. During the 1960s, saucers waned in popularity as UFOs were reported and depicted in other shapes. Discs ceased to be viewed as the standard shape for alien spacecraft but are still often depicted, sometimes for their retro value to evoke the early Cold War era.

History ðŸ”—

Reports of fantastical aircraft predate the first flying saucers. In antiquity, mysterious lights in the sky were interpreted as spiritual phenomena. In the 1800s, many newspapers reported massive airships with glowing lights and humming engines. These are often seen as precursors to flying saucer and UFO sightings. On January 25, 1878, the Denison Daily News printed an article in which John Martin, a local farmer, reported an object resembling a balloon flying “at wonderful speed”. The newspaper said it appeared to be about the size of a saucer from his perspective, one of the first uses of the word “saucer” in association with a UFO. An outbreak of a number of sightings of mystery airships occurred in America in 1896 and 1897. During World War II, Allied pilots reported balls of light following their planes. They named the lights foo fighters and believed they were advanced Axis aircraft.

Many aspects of the typical flying saucer first appeared in science fiction. French sociologist Bertrand MÃ©heust noted Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante (The Lightning Wheel). In the novel, a flying disc-shaped machine abducts the protagonists via a beam of light. Science fiction magazine Amazing Stories began publishing “The Shaver Mystery” in 1945. Written by Richard Sharpe Shaver and edited by Raymond A. Palmer, they were science fiction tales about technologically advanced “detrimental robots” that abducted humans, but the stories were presented as a true account of Shaver’s life. Until the magazine ceased printing The Shaver Mystery, Amazing Stories’ letter column was regularly full of readers sharing their own purportedly true sightings of the robots.

Before the flying saucer was coined as a term, fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicted flying discs. Skeptical physicist Milton Rothman noted the appearance of so-called flying saucers in the fantasy artwork of 1930s pulp science fiction magazines, by artists such as Frank R. Paul. One of Paul’s earliest depictions of a flying saucer appeared on the cover of the November 1929 issue of Hugo Gernsback’s pulp science fiction magazine Science Wonder Stories. Science fiction illustrator Frank Wu wrote that the idea of space vehicles shaped like flying saucers was imprinted in the national psyche for many years prior to 1947, when the Roswell incident took place.

Origins ðŸ”—

The modern flying saucer concept, including the association with aliens, can be traced to the 1947 Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting. On June 24, 1947, businessman and amateur pilot Kenneth Arnold landed at the Yakima, Washington airstrip. He told staff and friends that he’d seen nine unusual airborne objects. Arnold estimated their speed at 1,700 miles per hour, beyond the capabilities of known aircraft. Newspapers soon contacted Arnold for interviews. The East Oregonian reported his supposed aircraft as “saucer-like”. In a June 26 radio interview, Arnold described them as “something like a pie plate that was cut in half with a sort of a convex triangle in the rear”. Headline writers coined the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disk” (or “disc”) for the story. Arnold later told CBS News that the early coverage “did not quote me properly […] when I described how they flew, I said that they flew like they take a saucer and throw it across the water. Most of the newspapers misunderstood and misquoted that, too. They said that I said that they were saucer-like; I said that they flew in a saucer-like fashion.” The circular shape of typical flying saucers may be due to reporters mistaking Arnold’s “saucer-like” description of motion.

Arnold’s story preceded a wave of hundreds of flying saucer reports. Lieutenant Governor of Idaho Donald S. Whitehead claimed he saw a fast-moving object resembling a meteor around the time of Arnold’s sighting. In early July, head of Air Materiel Command Nathan F. Twining told reporters that “anyone seeing the objects” should contact Wright Field. The next widely publicized report was the sighting by a United Airlines crew on July 4 of nine more disc-like objects pacing their plane over Idaho.

The public was divided on the potential origin of the saucers. Arnold told military intelligence officers he suspected the discs were experimental aircraft, and early newspapers reported Arnold saying, “I don’t know what they wereâ€”unless they were guided missiles.” News media speculated on a Soviet origin, and many war veterans connected them to the foo fighters seen during World War II. A Gallup Poll found that 90% of Americans were aware of the saucer stories, and 16 percent believed they were secret military weapons, most likely American. The most common explanation given was some type of illusion or mirage. Less than one percent believed they were alien craft. One report from Seattle, Washington, described a hammer and sickle painted onto a flying disc. The stories spread to other countries, where they were influenced by local political and social concerns. In Europe, which was still recovering from the Second World War, saucers were often reported with rocket-like features. German newspapers reported flying saucers that exploded or had tails of fire. The names for the discs were largely derived from the English “flying saucer” including the French soucoupe volante, Spanish platillo volante, Portuguese disco voador, Swedish flygande tefat, German fliegende Untertasse, and Italian disco volante.

The 1947 sightings peaked in the days after the Fourth of July and declined rapidly through mid-July. Multiple organizations offered $1,000 rewards for hard proof. In the widely reported July 7, 1947, Twin Falls saucer hoax, four teenagers in Idaho fabricated a crashed disc from jukebox parts. On July 8, the Army Air Force base at Roswell, New Mexico, issued a press release saying that they had recovered a “flying disc” from a nearby ranch; the so-called Roswell UFO incident made front-page news. International media covered the military’s announcement of a crashed disc, but within 24 hours were reporting the military’s retraction and explanation that the material was balloon debris. By July 11, the most widely reported story was a North Hollywood resident’s claim that a 30-inch galvanized iron disc containing glass radio tubes had crashed in his garden. Newspapers quoted Fire Battalion Chief Wallace Newcombe’s assessment, “It doesn’t look to me like it could fly.”

The Air Force collected over a hundred reports at Wright Field, now Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio. Air Force General Nathan Twining established Project SAUCER, later renamed Project Sign, the first in a series of UFO investigations by the US Government. Other national governments followed suit. Canada began Project Magnet and the United Kingdom launched the Flying Saucer Working Party in 1950, which attributed saucer reports to meteorological phenomena, astronomical phenomena, misidentification, optical illusions, misconceptions, or hoaxes

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_Saucers

item.title: UFO sightings in the United States
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the United States ðŸ”—

This is a compilation of reported UFO sightings within the United States, presented in a table format. Each entry includes the date of the sighting, the city and state where it occurred, a link to a main article if available, and a brief description of the event.

Table of Sightings ðŸ”—

The table lists alleged UFO sightings chronologically, starting from September 1865 and extending to February 2023. Each row provides details about a specific incident.

  • September 1865, Cadotte Pass, Montana: Trapper James Lumley reported seeing a craft and its subsequent crash, noting sulfur smells and hieroglyphics.

  • 1896â€“1897, Multiple Locations, Multiple States: Sightings of airship-like vehicles were reported across the United States during this period, known as the Mystery airship wave.

  • April 17, 1897, Aurora, Texas: Residents claimed an airship crashed, and the deceased alien pilot was buried in the local cemetery.

  • February 24, 1942, Los Angeles, California: The “Battle of Los Angeles” involved an alleged enemy attack and anti-aircraft artillery barrage. Initially thought to be a Japanese attack, it was later attributed to “war nerves” and a possible weather balloon. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox called the incident a “false alarm.”

  • August 1945, Jornada del Muerto, New Mexico: Two boys reported seeing an “avocado-shaped” object crash, containing insect-like alien creatures, shortly after the first atomic bomb detonation.

  • June 21, 1947, Maury Island, Washington: This incident predates the Kenneth Arnold sighting and involves a reported encounter with “men in black” suits.

  • June 24, 1947, Mount Rainier, Washington: Kenneth Arnold reported seeing nine unusual objects flying in formation near Mount Rainier. His description of the objects’ erratic flight and tremendous speed gained widespread media attention.

  • July 1947, Roswell, New Mexico: The Roswell UFO Incident involves the recovery of materials near Roswell, becoming a subject of intense speculation. The military claims it was a crashed research balloon, while ufologists believe it was an alien craft.

  • January 7, 1948, Maysville, Kentucky: The Mantell Incident involved the death of Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a Kentucky Air National Guard pilot, while pursuing a UFO.

  • July 24, 1948, Montgomery, Alabama: The Chiles-Whitted UFO Encounter involves two commercial pilots reporting a near-collision with a torpedo-shaped object.

  • October 1, 1948, Fargo, North Dakota: The Gorman Dogfight involves a US Air Force pilot sighting and pursuing a UFO for 27 minutes.

  • May 11, 1950, McMinnville, Oregon: Paul and Evelyn Trent took the McMinnville UFO photographs on their farm.

  • May 29, 1950, Mount Vernon, Maryland: Captain Willis Sperry and crewmembers on an American Airlines DC-6 reported a “brilliant, diffused, bluish light.”

  • August 15, 1950, Great Falls, Montana: The Mariana UFO incident garnered national media attention during a period of high interest in UFOs and alien invasion.

  • August 25, 1951, Lubbock, Texas: The Lubbock Lights were a v-shaped formation of lights seen over the town.

  • May 24, 1952, Burbank, California: Orfeo Angelucci claimed to encounter flying saucers and their pilots during his drives home from an aircraft plant.

  • July 13, 1952, Washington, D.C.: The 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident involved multiple reports of unidentified flying objects over the city.

  • September 12, 1952, Flatwoods, West Virginia: Six boys and a woman reported seeing a UFO landing and a bizarre-looking creature.

  • November 23, 1953, Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan: Felix Moncla, Jr., a US Air Force pilot, disappeared with 2nd Lt. Robert Wilson while pursuing a UFO over Lake Superior.

  • November 2, 1957, Levelland, Texas: The Levelland UFO case involved multiple witnesses reporting unusual aerial phenomena.

  • September 19, 1961, Lancaster, New Hampshire: Betty and Barney Hill claimed to have been abducted by extraterrestrials, marking the first widely publicized UFO abduction report.

  • April 24, 1964, Socorro, New Mexico: Police officer Lonnie Zamora reported a close encounter with a UFO.

  • September 3, 1965, Exeter, New Hampshire: The Exeter incident involved multiple witnesses, including police officers, observing a large UFO.

  • December 9, 1965, Kecksburg, Pennsylvania: The Kecksburg UFO incident involved a large fireball seen over multiple states and Ontario, Canada, with reports of metal debris.

  • 1969, Leary, Georgia: Jimmy Carter claimed to have seen a UFO and filed a report with the International UFO Bureau.

  • October 11, 1973, Pascagoula, Mississippi: The Pascagoula Abduction involves Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker reporting an alien abduction.

  • January 12, 1975, North Bergen, New Jersey: The Stonehenge incident occurred near the Stonehenge apartment building in North Bergen.

  • November 5, 1975, Snowflake, Arizona: Travis Walton claims to have been abducted by a UFO while working on a logging crew.

  • December 17, 1977, Council Bluffs, Iowa: Local residents reported seeing a reddish fireball and a grass fire where molten metal was recovered.

  • August 27, 1979, Stephen, Minnesota: Deputy Sheriff Val Johnson’s patrol car was struck by a ball of light, causing damage and knocking him unconscious.

  • December 29, 1980, Dayton, Texas: The Cash-Landrum Incident involved a reported UFO sighting and subsequent health issues for the witnesses.

  • November 11, 1987, Gulf Breeze, Florida: The Gulf Breeze UFO incident occurred.

  • March 8, 1994, Multiple Locations, Michigan: Over 100 witnesses reported seeing objects with colored lights across West Michigan.

  • March 13, 1997, Phoenix, Arizona: The Phoenix Lights involved thousands of people witnessing lights of varying descriptions. Former Arizona governor Fife Symington admitted to seeing a delta-shaped craft.

  • January 5, 2000, Highland, Illinois: Five police officers and other witnesses reported a massive, silent, triangular aircraft.

  • August 21, 2004, Chicago, Illinois: A triangular formation of reddish lights was seen by hundreds of witnesses.

  • November 7, 2006, Chicago, Illinois: Airport employees reported a metallic, saucer-shaped craft hovering over O’Hare International Airport.

  • January 5, 2009, Morristown, New Jersey: Five red objects were seen over Morristown. The incident was later revealed to be a hoax by Joe Rudy and Chris Russo.

  • February 19, 2018, Desert, Arizona: Commercial pilots reported seeing an unidentified object, later attributed to a “high-altitude research balloon.”

  • February 21, 2021, Clayton, New Mexico: A pilot reported seeing a long cylindrical object moving rapidly.

  • February 10, 2023, Deadhorse, Alaska: A high-altitude object was shot down over the Beaufort Sea.

  • February 12, 2023, Lake Huron, Michigan: An octagonal object was detected and shot down over Lake Huron.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles, including:

  • List of reported UFO sightings
  • Psychological perspectives on UFO belief

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited within the article, providing links to external websites, news articles, and books that support the information presented.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sperry_UFO_case

item.title: Shag Harbour UFO incident
item.description:
Shag Harbour UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The Shag Harbour UFO incident refers to the reported crash of a large, unidentified object into the waters near Shag Harbour, Nova Scotia, on October 4, 1967. The incident was investigated by Canadian civilian and military agencies, as well as the U.S. Condon Committee.

Pre-incident Aerial Phenomenon ðŸ”—

This section details several aerial phenomena reported before the Shag Harbour incident.

Air Canada flight 305 ðŸ”—

Air Canada Flight 305, en route from Halifax to Toronto, experienced a sighting. First Officer Robert Ralph pointed out a strange object to Captain Pierre Charbonneau. The object was described as a brilliantly lit, rectangular shape with trailing lights, flying parallel to the aircraft. The pilots reported two silent explosions near the object.

Yellow object ðŸ”—

Darrel Dorey, along with his sister Kaykay and mother, witnessed a large object maneuvering in the southwestern horizon from their porch in Mahone Bay. Dorey wrote to the RCAF Greenwood Base Commander to inquire about the object.

MV Nickerson of Sambro, Nova Scotia ðŸ”—

Captain Leo Howard Mersey of the MV Nickerson observed four bright objects in a rectangular formation on his Decca radar and visually in the northeastern sky, approximately 28 kilometers from his vessel. The entire crew of nearly twenty fishermen witnessed the event. Mersey reported the sighting to the rescue coordination center and the harbor master in Halifax, and later filed a report with the Lunenburg RCMP.

Halifax Harbour sightings ðŸ”—

The Chronicle-Herald and local radio stations reported numerous sightings of a glowing object around Halifax at approximately 10:00 pm.

Initial events ðŸ”—

On October 4, 1967, at approximately 11:20 pm Atlantic Daylight Time, reports surfaced of an object crashing into the waters of Shag Harbour. At least eleven witnesses observed a low-flying, lit object heading towards the harbor, accompanied by whistling and whooshing sounds, followed by a loud bang. Laurie Wickens and four friends, driving on Highway 3, witnessed a large object descending into the water. They observed the object floating offshore and contacted the RCMP detachment in Barrington Passage, reporting a possible plane or airliner crash.

Search and rescue efforts ðŸ”—

Following the initial report, two RCMP officers arrived at the scene. The RCMP contacted the Rescue Coordination Centre (RCC) in Halifax to report the incident and inquire about missing aircraft. The object, still displaying lights, began to sink and disappeared from view before any rescue attempt could be initiated.

A rescue mission was assembled, with local fishing boats and a Canadian Coast Guard cutter dispatched to the crash site. No survivors, bodies, or debris were recovered. The next morning, RCC Halifax confirmed that no aircraft were missing. Despite this, the search continued.

RCC Halifax sent a telex to the “Air Desk” at air force headquarters in Ottawa, classifying the incident as a “UFO Report.” The Air Desk then sent a telex to navy headquarters, recommending an underwater search. Fleet Diving Unit Atlantic was tasked with carrying out the search.

Two days after the incident, navy divers from Fleet Diving Unit Atlantic searched the seafloor off Shag Harbour for three days. The final report indicated that no trace of an object was found.

Documents ðŸ”—

The Department of National Defence files at the national Library and Archives contain a summary of the event.

Press coverage ðŸ”—

The Shag Harbour incident received extensive coverage in the Halifax Chronicle-Herald. A headline story on October 7, titled “Could Be Something Concrete in Shag Harbour UFO â€“ RCAF,” detailed witness accounts, the air force’s search and rescue efforts, and the navy’s underwater search. Squadron Leader Bain, head of the air force’s “Air Desk,” expressed the air force’s strong interest in the matter.

Another article on October 9, titled “UFO Search Called Off,” reported the navy’s conclusion of the underwater search, stating that no trace of the object was found. The Canadian Press also carried the story of the search being called off.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shag_Harbour_UFO_incident

item.title: 1967 British flying saucer hoax
item.description:
1967 British Flying Saucer Hoax ðŸ”—

The 1967 British flying saucer hoax involved the supposed landing of six ‘spaceships’ across Southern England on September 4, 1967. These ‘spacecraft’ prompted a significant response from the police and army. The objects were described as being 54 inches long, 30 inches wide, and 20 inches deep, weighing 100 pounds, and emitting an electronic noise. The six craft were located along the 51st line of latitude, stretching from the Thames Estuary to the Bristol Channel. Specific locations included Queenborough on the Isle of Sheppey, Bromley golf course in south London, Winkfield village near Ascot, Welford near Newbury, Chippenham in Wiltshire, and Dial Hill in Clevedon, Somerset.

Planning and Building the ‘Spacecraft’ ðŸ”—

The hoax was conceived in January 1967 by aircraft engineering apprentices from the Royal Aircraft Establishment (RAE) at Farnborough as part of Rag Week. The apprentices constructed the flying saucers from fiberglass halves, covered them in metal, and equipped them with electronic devices to produce eerie sounds when flipped. Each saucer also contained a mixture of flour and water. Teams of two or three transported the saucers to the chosen locations at night, flipped them over to activate the sound, and then left the scene undetected.

Response from the Authorities ðŸ”—

The discovery of the saucers triggered a large-scale response from authorities. Police cordoned off each site, and the British army’s southern command, multiple police forces, army bomb disposal units, and RAF helicopters were mobilized. The Ministry of Defence was notified. The army detonated the saucer found in Chippenham, while the one on the Isle of Sheppey was removed by helicopter. Other saucers were sent to the Atomic Weapons Establishment at Aldermaston and the British Aircraft Corporation’s guided weapons division. When one of the saucers was drilled into, the mixture inside exploded, covering police officers in foul-smelling slime.

Revealing the Hoax ðŸ”—

Christopher Southall and Roger Palmer, both 21 years old, were identified as the pranksters behind the hoax. Their motive was to raise funds during Rag Week. The hoax generated extensive media coverage both in Britain and internationally. The apprentices revealed the hoax on the same day the saucers were found. No legal action was taken against them, and they successfully raised Â£2,000 for charity.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources used in the article, including BBC and The Guardian articles, and a GetSurrey news report.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to pictures of the hoax flying saucers.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1967_British_flying_saucer_hoax

item.title: Ground Crew Project
item.description:
Ground Crew Project ðŸ”—

The Ground Crew Project is a UFO religion originating in the United States, founded in the 1980s by Sheldan Nidle. It transitioned online in 1996 and later divided into the “Ground Crew” and “Planetary Activation Organisation.” The group anticipates a cosmic transformation of Earth, facilitated by a passage through a ‘photon belt’ and aided by the “Galactic Federation.” Members prepare for first contact, envisioning themselves as intermediaries between extraterrestrials and humanity. Despite failed predictions, the group maintains its belief in imminent contact and the need to elevate mankind’s consciousness.

Sheldan Nidle ðŸ”—

Sheldan Nidle, born in 1946, claims to have had extraterrestrial encounters from a young age, including telepathic communication and learning aboard spacecraft with ETs from Sirius. He published Youâ€™re Becoming a Galactic Human in 1994, detailing a childhood encounter. He claims regular communication with ETs since 1955, which he ceased at age 14 to fulfill his ‘star seed’ mission. He later became involved with the Amateur Astronomers Club and a film about Nikola Tesla. Nidle holds advanced degrees from Ohio University and the University of Southern California. In the mid-1980s, he resumed contact with the “Galactic Federation” and became a lecturer representing them.

Galactic Federation ðŸ”—

The Galactic Federation is described as an alliance of extraterrestrial civilizations within the Milky Way galaxy. This concept is popular in UFO religions and New Age movements.

Haim Eshed’s claims ðŸ”—

In 2020, Haim Eshed, former head of Israel’s military space program, claimed that aliens have contacted representatives of the United States and Israel, but humanity is not ready for contact. He stated that aliens are present on Earth and have formed a “Galactic Federation” to avoid mass hysteria until humanity is ready. NASA responded by stating that no extraterrestrial life has been found, but the search continues.

Photon Belt ðŸ”—

Beginning in 1996, Nidle channeled messages about an imminent apocalypse due to Earth’s planetary transformation. He claimed to lead a mission for the “Galactic Federation of Planets” to prepare the world for this transformation as the planet passes into a cosmic ‘photon belt’. This area of space supposedly has high energy properties that would transform Earth into a pristine state and restore superhuman abilities by altering human DNA to a 12-helix pattern. The pineal gland would be activated, and humans would regain cosmic abilities like rejuvenation, telepathy, and overcoming illness. The channeling claimed that human structures would be destroyed, and the only safe places would be underground or in spaceships.

Imminent Landing ðŸ”—

The narrative stated that a mass landing of 15 million starships of the “Galactic Federation” would occur no later than December 17, 1996, to raise humanity’s consciousness using advanced technology, achieving a galactic and divine society by 2012. The landing would involve advanced races like Pleiadians, Sirians, Cassopeans, and Arcturians, who would meet and placate human populations. Earthly weapons would be neutralized, mechanical devices shut down, and world government taken over by the Spiritual Hierarchy. The Earth transformation would include telepathy, airborne transport, and photon energy generators. This is considered a “cargoistic” belief, where alien “cargo” brings about human ascension.

Ground Crew ðŸ”—

The “Ground Crew” refers to the virtual congregation who join the mission. Members were told they would assist humanity and the extraterrestrials as councillors and ambassadors. They would be trained by space forces and receive implants. After failed predictions, the emphasis shifted to spiritual development, requiring the Ground Crew to help raise humanity spiritually and assist in ecological restoration. This involved gathering humanity through world meditation days to harmonize vibrations and creating a ’network of light’ with other new age groups.

Landings delayed ðŸ”—

The December 1996 mass landing did not occur, but Nidle continued to spread messages that spaceships would appear soon. Further dates, including the Gregorian New Year and spring of 1997, also passed without a landing. Delays were attributed to a solar storm and planetary instability. Details about the comet Hale-Bopp were communicated, and the number of spaceships in the landing fleet was increased to 25 million.

Hale-Bopp ðŸ”—

A new landing date was set to coincide with the arrival of the Hale-Bopp comet on May 5, 1997. The comet was described as a large spaceship with cloaking and holographic systems, containing a crew of over 200,000 beings and 10,000 ambassadors. This would coincide with the mass landing by the Federation. After the mass suicide of Heaven’s Gate members, the Ground Crew distanced themselves from such acts. Instead of a mass landing, a meeting between a shuttle from the comet and a shuttle from the “Galactic Federation Fleet” took place near Ayers Rock in Australia, where a ceremony was conducted, and papers were exchanged.

Further re-scheduling and shift in focus ðŸ”—

Nidle and the Ground Crew blamed repeated failed prophecies on external factors, such as dark forces conspiring with ‘planetary elites’. Messages began to deny the relevance of specific arrival dates and talked about “the right divine time.” The focus shifted to humans assisting in the planet’s transformation before galactic intervention. Salvation became a two-way street, determined by human attitudes. A more spiritual content appeared, referring to beings like Ashtar Sheran, Aaron Alaje, Megha Alcorn, Merku Alcorn, Great White Brotherhood, Ascended Masters, and archangels.

Split ðŸ”—

In December 1997, Nidle split with Valerie Donnell, his secretary and the Ground Crew’s chief administrator. Donnell retained the Ground Crew name and website, posting channeled messages with a UFO content focused on personal spiritual transformation from a new age perspective. Nidle founded the Planetary Activation Organisation, restructuring it as the only source for messages about the Galactic Federation. He established a hierarchical system and created a “Web of Light” to unite like-minded groups.

Evolution of the narrative ðŸ”—

According to Nidle’s channeling, the Federation remained dedicated to first contact, but the spiritual transformation of humans became the main focus. Earth rulers were identified as a secret cabal, but would be removed by the Federation. ‘Star Gates’ were being placed in the upper atmosphere, and ‘Galactic and Medical Teams’ were assisting people during sleep. Earth was portrayed as a vitally important planet due to humanity’s exalted role, acting as a switch in the spiritual transformation of the Milky Way. By 2000, the movement continued to develop its membership base, claiming hundreds of Planetary Activation Groups in over 29 countries. The Planetary Activation Organisation is classified as a progressive millennialist group promising collective salvation and a terrestrial paradise.

Credibility ðŸ”—

The Ground Crew employed strategies to avoid prophetic disconfirmation and cognitive dissonance, such as disclaimers and exploiting temporality. Nidle reconceptualized the movement through spiritualization, changing the focus from a UFO landing to the need for humans to raise their own spirituality. Due to the virtual nature of the group, it is impossible to accurately account for membership. The movement’s period of failed prophecy is no longer online. The online narrative functions like fiction, conveying a vivid imaginary world and apocalyptic expectancy.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_Federation_(ufology)

item.title: Narrative of the abduction phenomenon
item.description:
Narrative of the Abduction Phenomenon ðŸ”—

This article explores the alleged core similarities in claims of alien abduction experiences. Proponents believe these similarities point to an objective reality, while skeptics attribute them to psychological and cultural factors. Skeptics also suggest that some reports are hoaxes. Believers argue that the independent generation of similar narratives by individuals is unlikely. Some investigators attempt to confirm abduction claims through observation or experimentation, but these efforts are often dismissed as pseudoscientific.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section outlines the typical sequence of events in an alien abduction narrative, according to UFO researchers like folklorist Thomas E. Bullard. The sequence includes capture, examination, conference, tour, loss of time, return, theophany, and aftermath. It notes that not all abductions feature all events and that some researchers, like Budd Hopkins and David M. Jacobs, have been accused of selectively using data to fit a specific paradigm.

Nyman’s Alternate Outline ðŸ”—

This section presents an alternative model for abduction narratives composed by abduction researcher Joe Nyman. The model includes anxious anticipation, transition of consciousness, psycho-physical imposition, reassurance, transition back to normal consciousness, rapid forgetfulness, a marker stage, and a cycle interval. David M. Jacobs is quoted, emphasizing the orchestrated nature of abduction events. The section also mentions the connection between alien abductions and UFO reports, as well as the common portrayal of abductors as “Greys.”

Capture ðŸ”—

This section details the events leading up to the alleged abduction. It describes unusual feelings, such as a compulsive desire to be in a certain place or expectations of something unknown. Abductees report a shift in consciousness, often accompanied by lights and a strange mist. They may be levitated into an alien craft, sometimes through solid objects. The section also mentions scenarios involving automobiles, UFO sightings, mechanical failures, and amnesia. The use of a pencil-sized device by the aliens to ensure compliance is also noted.

Examination ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the medical procedures and examinations performed by alien beings during the abduction. It highlights the differences between these procedures and typical human medicine, as noted by physician and abduction researcher John G. Miller. The section discusses the abductors’ areas of interest, such as the cranium, nervous system, skin, and reproductive system, as well as the lack of gloves and other standard medical practices.

Cranial Procedures ðŸ”—

This section details the specific procedures allegedly performed on the abductee’s head. Yvonne Smith, a hypnotherapist and abduction researcher, notes similarities in reports of hypnotically retrieved abduction memories. Common procedures include feelings of pressure, insertion of needles into the scalp, drilling into the skull, and procedures involving the ears and nasal passages.

Reproductive, Gynecological and Urological Procedures ðŸ”—

This section describes the gynecological aspects of the abduction experience reported by many female abductees. It notes the absence of standard gynecological practices. Reports of sex with human-alien hybrids or other abductees are mentioned. The insertion of a long needle-like contraption into a woman’s navel is also discussed.

Other Procedures ðŸ”—

This section covers other procedures reported by abductees, such as skin scrapings. Physician and abduction researcher John Altshuler dismisses speculation that the aliens are collecting skin samples to analyze DNA.

Reported Devices and Instruments ðŸ”—

This section describes the devices and instruments allegedly used by the aliens during the abduction. It mentions a black, cylindrical device with a bluish light used to render abductees compliant. The placement of devices on the chest and the use of diffused colored lights are also discussed.

Subsequent Abduction Procedures ðŸ”—

This section details procedures that occur after the medical exam, including imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing. Imaging involves viewing screens with emotionally provocative images. Envisioning involves images projected into the abductee’s mind. Staging involves the abductee interacting with an illusionary scenario. Testing involves operating a complicated electronic device.

Child Presentation ðŸ”—

This section describes the “child presentation” phase, where abductees are shown hybrid children. It is speculated that these children are the products of reproductive procedures. Folklorist Thomas Bullard could not identify this phase in his study of abduction reports. The section discusses the varying ages of the hybrid children, their roles in assisting the abductors, and the expectations placed on the abductees during the presentation.

Less Common Elements ðŸ”—

This section discusses less prominent aspects of abduction claims, based on a study by folklorist Thomas E. Bullard. These elements include the conference, the tour, the journey, and theophany.

Conference ðŸ”—

This section describes the conference phase, where the entities engage in discussions with the abductee. The discussions may involve interrogation sessions, explanatory segments, task assignments, warnings, and prophecies.

Tour ðŸ”—

This section discusses the rare occurrence of tours of the abductors’ craft. Abduction claimants often find the “engine room” to be the most memorable aspect.

Journey ðŸ”—

This section describes reports of further transport within the abductors’ vessel, sometimes to other planets. The abductee may be placed in a protective environment, such as a chamber filled with liquid.

Theophany ðŸ”—

This section discusses the rare experience of “theophany,” a sense of oneness with the universe or with God. Psychologist Susan A. Clancy notes that abductees often feel “changed” by their experiences.

Return ðŸ”—

This section describes the return of the abductees to Earth, usually to the same location and circumstances they were in prior to being taken. Explicit memories of the abduction experience are usually absent, and the abductee may realize they have experienced “missing time.” The section also mentions instances where the abductors appear to make mistakes when returning their captives.

Missing Time ðŸ”—

This section highlights the phenomenon of “missing time” in abduction accounts. Don C. Donderi notes that there is often independent confirmation of missing time, as well as confirmation of abduction events reported under hypnosis.

Realization Event ðŸ”—

This section discusses the “realization event,” the insight or development leading a person to see themselves as being a victim of the abduction phenomenon. Physician and abduction researcher John G. Miller identifies common triggers for the realization event, such as tangible evidence, conversations with other abductees, exposure to depictions of the abduction phenomenon in popular culture, and hypnotic retrieval of abduction memories.

Skeptical Response ðŸ”—

This section presents the skeptical perspective on the abduction phenomenon.

Role of Hypnosis and Investigators in Shaping the Narrative ðŸ”—

This section discusses how individual abduction researchers appear to exert influence on the characteristics of narratives retrieved during hypnotic recall. Skeptics Robert Sheaffer and Phillip J. Klass argue that this influence reinforces the preconceived biases of the researcher.

Effect of Geography and Culture on Abduction Reports ðŸ”—

This section discusses the variation in abduction reports across cultures and geographic boundaries. Skeptics assert that this variation supports a psycho-social hypothesis as an explanation for the origin of the abduction phenomenon. The section also notes that the contents and structure of the “abduction narrative” were already established in fictional form by 1930 in a Buck Rogers strip.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narrative_of_the_abduction_phenomenon

item.title: Alien Terminator (1988 film)
item.description:
Alien Terminator (1988 film) ðŸ”—

This article details the 1988 Italian film Alien Terminator, also known as Top Line. It distinguishes it from the 1995 film of the same name.

Top Line ðŸ”—

This section provides the original Italian title of the film, which is Top Line.

Film Details ðŸ”—

This section presents key information about the film in a table format:

  • Director: Nello Rossati (also credited as Ted Archer)
  • Writers: Roberto Gianviti and Nello Rossati
  • Stars: Franco Nero and George Kennedy
  • Cinematography: Mario DiLeo
  • Editor: Adalberto Ceccarelli
  • Music: Maurizio Dami
  • Release Date: 1988
  • Country: Italy
  • Language: Italian

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot revolves around Ted Angelo, an alcoholic writer who discovers a 16th-century Spanish ship inside a mountain cave in Cartagena, Colombia. He learns the cave is actually the inside of a crashed UFO. He is pursued by hitmen, a Nazi fugitive named Heinrich Holzmann, and CIA operatives. He teams up with art historian June and eventually involves his ex-wife Maureen. Maureen is revealed to be an alien who has been disguising herself as a human and manipulating world events. She is killed by June. Ted and June go into hiding with an indigenous tribe, where Ted continues to write about his experiences.

Cast ðŸ”—

This section lists the main actors and their respective roles in the film:

  • Franco Nero as Ted Angelo
  • George Kennedy as Heinrich Holzmann
  • Deborah Moore (credited as Deborah Barrymore) as June
  • Mary Stavin as Maureen De Havilland
  • William Berger as Alonso Kintero
  • Shirley Hernandez as Juanita
  • Larry Dolgin
  • Robert Redcross

Release ðŸ”—

This section details the film’s release information. It was released theatrically in Germany on September 22, 1988. It was released on Region 1 DVD on May 25, 2004. It is also available for streaming on platforms like Amazon.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes critical reception of the film. Sci-Fi 100 noted the initial lack of science fiction elements but found the last 30 minutes more engaging. Film Authority described the film as a mix of Romancing the Stone, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and The Terminator.

See also ðŸ”—

This section lists a related film:

  • Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)
  • List of Italian films of 1988

References ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of citations used in the article, including books, websites, and databases.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the film’s IMDb page.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Terminator_(1988_film)

item.title: Jafr alien invasion
item.description:
2010 Jordanian Newspaper Prank: The Jafr Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

This article details the events surrounding a prank published by the Jordanian newspaper Al-Ghad on April 1, 2010. The prank involved a fabricated story about UFOs landing near the town of Jafr, Jordan, and the panic that ensued among the town’s residents.

Summary ðŸ”—

The article on the front page of Al-Ghad claimed that UFOs had landed in the desert near Jafr, and the “pilots” were described as 3-meter-tall creatures. The story also stated that communications were disrupted by the UFOs.

Details of the Prank and Reaction ðŸ”—

The story elaborated on the alien landing, describing how the town was illuminated by the flying saucers at night, causing residents to flee into the streets. The hoax caused widespread fear in Jafr, leading parents to keep their children home from school. The mayor of Jafr, Mohammed Mleihan, contacted security authorities and considered ordering an evacuation of the town’s 13,000 residents. He also expressed the residents’ fear of an alien attack and considered suing the newspaper for spreading false information.

Apology and Context ðŸ”—

The newspaper issued a formal apology for the disruption caused by the prank. The editor did not explain why Jafr was chosen as the target of the joke. However, the BBC noted that the area is known for its military bases, which have been used by American soldiers for joint exercises with the Jordanian military and had allegedly housed al-Qaida militants in the past.

Comparison and Cultural Context ðŸ”—

The prank is compared to the 1938 radio broadcast of War of the Worlds, which caused panic in the United States. The article emphasizes that April Fool’s Day jokes are not a common practice in Jordanian newspapers.

References ðŸ”—

The article cites two sources: a BBC article titled “‘Alien invasion’ April Fools’ story angers Jordan mayor” and a USA Today article titled “‘Alien invasion’ April Fools prank causes public panic.”

External Links ðŸ”—

The article provides an external link to the original article in Arabic on the Al-Ghad website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jafr_alien_invasion

item.title: Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting
item.description:
Nash-Fortenberry UFO Sighting ðŸ”—

The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting occurred on July 14, 1952, when two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported seeing eight UFOs in a tight echelon formation over Chesapeake Bay in Virginia.

Description ðŸ”—

Two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported observing eight UFOs flying in formation over Chesapeake Bay, Virginia. Ufologists highlight the pilots’ observation allowed for measurements of the objects’ motion and size relative to known landmarks. The sighting was reportedly corroborated by independent ground witnesses. Project Blue Book listed the case as an “unknown.”

Explanations ðŸ”—

Donald Howard Menzel suggested the pilots might have seen distorted ground lights due to haze or fireflies trapped in the cockpit window. Steuart Campbell proposed the sighting was a mirage of Venus.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article:

  1. A NICAP report by Thomas Thulien revisiting the Nash/Fortenberry sighting.
  2. Donald Howard Menzel’s book, The World of Flying Saucers, where he offers naturalistic explanations.
  3. Steuart Campbell’s book, The UFO Mystery Solved, where he suggests the sighting was a mirage of Venus.

Further Reading ðŸ”—

This section lists additional resources for further information:

  • Steuart Campbell’s book, The UFO Mystery Solved.
  • James W. Moseley and Karl T. Pflock’s book, Shockingly Close to the Truth: Confessions of a Grave-Robbing Ufologist.

External Links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external resources:

  • “The Pilots’ Tale” at Saturday Night Uforia.
  • “We Flew Above Flying Saucers” by William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, published in True magazine in 1967.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash-Fortenberry_UFO_sighting

item.title: James Harder
item.description:
James A. Harder ðŸ”—

James Albert Harder was a professor of civil and hydraulic engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, and later a professor emeritus. He also had a notable interest in ufology.

Engineering ðŸ”—

Harder taught civil engineering at various levels, emphasizing practical aspects like lab experiments and model testing. While he didn’t publish extensively, his work was recognized for its quality. He made significant contributions to flow simulations before computers were widely used. A paper he co-authored, Sea Water Intrusion in California, received an award in 1957. His work was applied in Suisun Bay and the Mekong Delta, and he also studied fish protection facilities. Later in his career, he studied fluid mechanics in a medical context, working on artificial hearts, endoscopes, and colostomy equipment.

Ufology ðŸ”—

Harder believed that unidentified flying objects were extraterrestrial beings. He testified before the House of Representatives Committee on Science and Astronautics and was involved with the Aerial Phenomena Research Organization (APRO).

Education ðŸ”—

Harder’s education included:

  • B.S. from the California Institute of Technology in 1948.
  • M.S. in Civil Engineering from UC Berkeley in 1952.
  • Ph.D. in Fluid Mechanics from UC Berkeley in 1957.

Career ðŸ”—

Harder’s career included:

  • U.S. Navy as an electronics technician (1944-45).
  • Design Engineer for the soil conservation service, U.S. Department of Agriculture (1948â€“50).
  • Resident engineer at UC Berkeley (1952â€“57).
  • Assistant professor of hydraulic engineering at UC Berkeley (1957â€“62).
  • Associate professor of civil engineering at UC Berkeley (1962â€“70).
  • Professor of civil engineering at UC Berkeley (1970â€“91).
  • Professor emeritus at UC Berkeley (1991).

Organizations ðŸ”—

Harder was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE). He was also a founding member of the Society for Scientific Exploration.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Harder_(ufologist)

item.title: Unidentified flying object (disambiguation)
item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (Disambiguation) ðŸ”—

This page serves as a disambiguation for the term “Unidentified flying object” and related variations. It directs users to different articles based on their intended meaning.

Definition ðŸ”—

The primary meaning of “Unidentified flying object” refers to a perceived aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified or explained. This is the common understanding of the term, often associated with extraterrestrial speculation.

Music ðŸ”—

This section lists musical works that use the term “Unidentified flying object” or variations in their titles.

  • UFO 1: A 1970 album by the British rock band UFO, which was reissued under the title Unidentified Flying Object.
  • The Unidentified Flying Object: A 1966 electronica song by Perrey and Kingsley.
  • (The Notes) Unidentified Flying Objects: A 2013 jazz song by Wayne Shorter from his album Without a Net.
  • The Unidentified Flying Objects: A US rock band led by Lisa Kindred.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to another disambiguation page, “UFO (disambiguation)”. This suggests that “UFO” is a common abbreviation for “Unidentified flying object” and that there are other topics associated with this shorter form.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unidentified_flying_object_(disambiguation)

item.title: Alien visitation
item.description:
Alien Visitation ðŸ”—

This entry directs readers to the Wiktionary definition of “visitation.”

Alien visitation refers to the concept that intelligent extraterrestrial beings have visited Earth. Several claimed forms of these visitations are listed:

  • Alien abduction: The act of being kidnapped by aliens.
  • Ancient astronaut: The theory that aliens influenced major historical events.
  • Close encounter: The observation of alien vessels.
  • Contactee: A person who claims to have been contacted by aliens.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to a disambiguation page for the term “Visitation,” indicating that the term has multiple meanings beyond the context of alien encounters. It also includes a standard disambiguation notice, explaining that the page lists articles associated with the title “Alien visitation” and advising users to correct internal links that may have led them there unintentionally.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_visitation
